4$Condition: Anxiousness associated with Depression$10/15/2019 3:53:35 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$5$My doctor prescribed this due to my concern over constantly crying over stressful situations (due to anxiety and major depression) and it was happening on a daily basis. It was so bad that I couldn't work. The Lexapro really helped rather quickly. I'd say within a week or two I started noticing changes. I still think the same but I can brush things off that normally would make me cry. I pretty much feel like I things don't bother me as severely as they did. Sure
column2: I still get sad and feel down at times
column3: but they don't make me feel like it's the end of the world and I don't cry whenever I feel stressed.

column1: 5$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$10/11/2019 3:09:38 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$Don't let all the bad reviews scare you--Lexapro has given me my life back. I was having almost daily panic attacks in grad school
column2: it was so bad I considered dropping out. But then I got prescribed Lexapro and saw an instant improvement. Even from day 1 my mood was better and more stable
column3: and by the end of two weeks my panic attacks had completely vanished. My doctor had me start at a very low dose and slowly increase to my full dose over a two-week period. I noticed mild headaches on the days I upped the dosage
column4: and I had increased daytime sleepiness for the first month
column5: but I've had no other side effects aside from mild headaches if I accidentally miss a dose. Totally worth it for me
column6: it's made me so much happier and healthier!

column1: 8$Condition: Panic Disorder$8/19/2019 1:31:46 PM$Reviewer: bradak
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$"I'm very satisfied with Lexapro.  I had a mental breakdown around the 4th of July due to two tragedies in the family
column3: and heightened day to day stresses.  I kept going into the ER thinking I was having a heart attack or stroke and they kept calling it anxiety / panic attacks.  Got with my primary doctor and he prescribed me 10mg/day Lexapro.  I had severe issues my first week and a half of Lexapro including no appetite
column4: constant nausea
column5: fell asleep easy but would wake up through-out the night
column6: sometimes awake for hours.  Very vivid dreams. Panic attacks continued
column7: but they were less frequent and less severe.  This all passed by about day 21.  I haven't had any of these symptoms in about 3 weeks.  Doctor told me he likes to get people on Lexapro long before I started it.  So what i learned was open up with your doctor
column8: be honest.

column1: I had a diary I started which had paragraphs each day documented when I had bad days
column2: but after the 3 week mark they are few and far between
column3: due mostly to this pill."

column1: 11$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$7/21/2019 11:11:59 PM$Reviewer: $1$1$1$I'm writing this review on every site I can find in hopes that it will help somebody going through what I went through on this drug. I was prescribed lexapro for some moderate anxiety I was having caused by a physical injury. I took the first 10mg pill in the morning and that night had a full blown panic attack. I had never experienced anything like that prior. I took one more pill the next morning and it led to the 4 worst days of my life. I couldn't eat or sleep and certainly couldn't work. My mind was racing non stop and the anxiety was ceaseless and I broke down crying several times. I spent all day pacing around my living room terrified that this change was somehow permanent
column2: I was going to lose my job and my life was over. I took four days for the medication to leave my system and I was myself again. If you are experiencing this
column3: just hang in there! It will get better again!

Had to discontinue right away. Might effect tonight also. Some people it might not do this to them.. just did it to me. Thanks!

26$Condition: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder$12/17/2018 3:33:54 AM$Reviewer: Ahmed, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$4$I have always suffered with Severe Pure O OCD, it had severely impacted almost every single aspect of my life which lead me to severe crippling Anxiety, Social Anxiety, Panic Disorder and Mild Depression. I tried numerous types of Medication, even the BIG ONE - Anafranil, I remained on this medication for several months on a high dosage, it assisted with the OCD (not so much with Anxiety) however the side effects were utterly terrible so decided to give it up. My psychiatrist suggested Lexapro, began on 5mg and slowly work my way up to 30mg (currently on this dosage for the last three months). Pros: Anxiety has greatly reduced, very few panic attacks, hasn't stopped the thoughts however they have become much easier to brush off, I am able to think more rationally, and I feel somewhat more hopeful and optimistic. Cons: Constantly tired, extremely sleepy (I could sleep all day if I wanted to) and at times I feel somewhat emotionally numb.

column1: Maybe this works for some

column1: 28$Condition: Anxiousness associated with Depression$12/13/2018 5:42:02 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$I have had anxiety off and on for years
column2: but it was always controllable. However
column3: it became more and more progressive over the past few months where my anxiety would trigger full blown panic attacks. One day
column4: I woke up feeling extremely anxious and it did not go away all day. The anxiety progressed so fast where I had episodes of trembling throughout the day
column5: completely lost my appetite
column6: and would even wake up in the middle of the night with extreme anxiety. the anxiety took over and It was all I could think about. It became so debilitating
column7: just trying to go to the store was the hardest task in the world and I was terrified to do so. My anxiety triggered deep depression. I am usually very full of energy
column8: work out
column9: and happy. I have a full time job
column10: and two young kids so I knew I had to see a doctor and get things figured out. I was diagnosed with Generalized Anxiety Disorder and Depression. I am not one to take medicine and am usually scared to do so
column11: but anything was worth a try at this point. I was prescribed 10mg of Lexapro and within a week
column12: felt a difference. It has been 2.5 weeks now
column13: and I feel like myself again and like I have my life back. The medicine helped with my anxiety first
column14: so I still felt my depression until about the second week. I personally haven't experienced any crazy side effects yet
column15: and feel a headache or a little weight gain (if that does happen) is way better than the extreme anxiety and depression I was battling. My Dr.'s goal is to slowly lower my dose after a few months until I am good to be completely off it
column16: as she believes my diagnosis is situational. This medicine truly saved me and gave me my life back. You just have to stick with it!

column1: 29$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$11/11/2018 1:09:15 AM$Reviewer: Angie
column2: 25-34 on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$1$"I took Lexapro once
column3: and I still have not gotten myself to take another dose. I was prescribed 10mg of Lexapro by my NP for anxiety and depression. I haven't taken any psychiatric medication since high school for my conditions. After I filled my prescription
column4: I took my dose at 1pm. By 4pm
column5: I was feeling elated
column6: lightheaded
column7: and had some stomach pains. By 6pm
column8: I experienced severe dry mouth
column9: excessive sweating
column10: and remained lightheaded and hazy feeling. My heart was also beginning to race. By 9pm
column11: along with the previous symptoms
column12: my blood pressure was very high
column13: my jaw was clenching
column14: and leg muscles were cramping
column15: and I was feeling short of breath. I felt wired. I felt like I had taken a small dose of ecstacy (speaking from personal experience). I was extremely uncomfortable and just wanted to sleep for work. By 11:30pm
column16: I had my mother take me to the ER
column17: and I was given IV saline and an Ativan. My blood pressure while in the ER was around 180/110
column18: and my heart rate was 135. Around 2am
column19: all of my adverse signs and symptoms subsided
column21: and I was finally able to sleep. Be careful of Lexapro
column22: as it is not meant for everyone. Because Lexapro is an SSRI
column23: it can potentially cause something called ""SEROTONIN SYNDROME
column24: which is what I experienced. It can also cause this syndrome from interactions with other medication
column25: even as simple as Nyquil. I was told to just try to tough it out and keep taking the Lexapro because ""it will get better when my body adjusts to it
column26: but I really do not want to risk going through that again. Make sure you talk with your doctor so that you are well-informed before starting this medication."

column1: 42$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$6/2/2018 5:05:16 AM$Reviewer: Sarah
column2: 13-18 on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$I've suffered from anxiety my whole life and it really had just got worse as I got older. When I moved schools the start of this year when I was sixteen I started getting panic attacks and was just not functioning at all. I just hated myself and was so angry with how I was. I got put on Lexapro 10mg and it has been the best decision I've ever made. Within the first half an hour of taking it I felt so much better. I got a bit of a high off it which apparently some people get. Also felt so calm like there was nothing in my head. After the first week it felt more normal. Now I love it life is just so much easier and I'm happier. I will probably be on it for a few years and to be honest I don't really want to get off it because it helps so much. Also though I don't want to be on it my whole life. Side effects I get are headaches and shaking/ jumpyness.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$4$5$"My anxiety hit a high in my mid 20s & went from every once in a while to a constant drowning feeling of anxiety. When it became paralyzing
column3: I started therapy. After 4 months of therapy & being against medication
column4: I started to learn more about the illness
column5: how it runs in my family & because the physical symptoms weren't going away I started Lexapro.

column1: For the first couple of months as I increased the dosage
column2: I became extremely paranoid that I was going to become suicidal. The weird part was that I had never even thought about this before and never experienced symptoms of depression. I started to learn through therapy that it stemmed from my fear of losing control of my anxiety and myself and the worst case scenario of that would be killing myself.

column1: I then became extremely motivated to become the best version of myself that I could be. With more therapy
column2: daily mental exercises
column3: physical exercise and A LOT of hard work... I was able to shake the paranoid thoughts and have never appreciated life more than I do now. Lexapro helped with the physical symptoms but if you suffer from anxiety and panic disorder you still need therapy. The medication is just one part of the process. But with all of the hard work and a daily pep talk in the mirror
column4: I am a completely different person than I was 1 year ago when I hit rock bottom.

column1: I see life different & I am so grateful for the little things because I once couldn't enjoy them because of my anxiety and physical sickness. For those who are suffering from anxiety
column2: this is how I see it. Every day I may get a wave here & there but I can manage it and still be happy. If that is the worst thing I have to deal with that day
column3: I will take it. Anxiety is 100% manageable and YOU HAVE CONTROL. It's all about really believing you have control and that YOU ARE NOT A VICTIM. I think it's really important we start more conversations about mental illness. We shouldn't be ashamed or afraid.I encourage all of you to keep preaching ways to overcome it"

column4: I woke up and threw up violently then proceeded to have wave after wave of panic attacks for the next 5-6 hours. The next night
column5: I took the drug and told myself that the first night was probably just my body adjusting to the new medication and that I would be fine and it wouldn't happen again. But it happened again. And again. And again. I had constant panic attacks for about 2 weeks before I just stopped taking the drug. I couldn't handle it. I wasn't sleeping at all. And my doctor had the nerve to tell me that I caused the panic attacks - but I wasn't causing them - I'm well versed in panic attacks and I know when I'm causing them and when they just happen. I don't recommend just stopping the drug like I did because that could REALLY MESS YOU UP but I made sure I was watched for a couple days after I stopped taking it in case something happened. The antidepressant part actually did work - I felt a lot better and that ""heavy cloud"" feeling was gone but I just couldn't handle the panic attacks so I decided to deal with the depression on my own and it took longer than I wanted but it's gone now and I didn't ever go back on a drug to do it. "

column3: couldn’t sleep (literally)

I had never been on any in my life and didn’t want to start.  My Doctor prescribed me 5mg of Lexapro for 6 months.  Long story short
column10: Lexapro saved my life.  It’s as simple as that.  The side effects I experienced the first 10-14 days were absolutely horrible: I basically experienced every reported side effect for at least a few days

Like the entire miserable 3 month anxiety episode I had just gone through was just a dream.  Had I bailed after 5-6 miserable days and not stuck with it
column13: I don’t know what would have happened to me.  I finished my Doctor prescribed course of 6 months and its like the entire thing never happened. I'm back to myself 100% because of Lexapro.

column1: 148$Condition: Depression$5/9/2015 5:02:45 AM$Reviewer: JP
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$"I've always had intense anxiety and obsessive-compulsive tendencies. I've been diagnosed with PTSD
column3: depression
column4: anorexia
column5: EDNOS
column6: anxiety disorder.

column1: A year ago
column2: after a 20-year battle
column3: I admitted myself into residential treatment for an eating disorder. The eating disorderwas my coping mechanism to self medicate
column4: in a sense: starvation made my highs less intense and gave me purpose during my depressive lows.

column1: Without my usual coping mechanisms
column2: the depression didn’t lift. After two months wondering what the point of it all was
column3: in nearly unbearable physical and mental pain
column4: with NOTHING I could think of that would make me happy
column5: I realized I needed help.

column1: So I saw a psychiatrist who put me on 5 mg of Lexapro.
The very first day
column2: I felt it. I know that’s rare
column3: but I’m super sensitive. I entertained the possibility of it being a placebo effect
column4: but I know it’s not. How?

column1: Well
column2: I’ve been a nervous sweater my whole life. I drench my clothes in tense situations
column3: in freezing cold
column4: in heat. The first day on Lexapro
column5: the sweating went from excessive to normal. This is not something you can change with a placebo effect.

column1: The pain in my chest started to ease
column2: I noticed colors and sounds and smells in a pleasant way rather than not noticing them at all
column3: or being totally overwhelmed by them.

column1: I could face the everyday tasks that had felt impossible before. I started feeling for the first time in my life
column2: “This must be a bit what it feels like to be a normal person.”

column1: It’s been two and a half weeks. I had a few side effects initially: dry mouth
column2: clenching jaw
column3: foggy head
column4: loss of appetite
column5: hot puffy hands and feet
column6: and a surge of foggy exhaustion for about two hours after taking my morning 5 mg pill.

column1: It subsided within a week. It’s completely even now.

I have a full range of emotions. I don’t feel the meds now. I just feel like I can breathe a little better. I have a little more strength to face the every day things. I even feel joy again now and then. "

column1: 161$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$1/29/2015 1:02:46 PM$Reviewer: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $1$1$4$"In the June of 2014
column2: I was put on Lexapro for anxiety after supposed paranoia caused from anxiety alone. As all antidepressants
column3: nothing kicked in for a couple of weeks. By August
column4: there was a week that I had an extreme manic episode. I basically acted how you would assume somebody on methamphetamine was on. The medication actually made me more paranoid
column5: and I ended up overdosing on my medication (the first suicide attempt of two in the past six months). My doctor did not want me on an antidepressant
column6: for I acted the same way on the last one. Be wary and don't be afraid of asking questions

column8: as me (14). If there is any history of Bipolar Disorder (even if it is only supposed)
column9: be wary as possible. I would've never expected a mental health disorder
column10: especially one as dangerous as Bipolar Disorder. Make sure you are closely monitored
column11: even if you act ""happy as can be"". If it's excessive

column1: 181$Condition: Depression$9/28/2014 4:15:20 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$"After a terrible experience with fluoxetine in the past

column1: 183$Condition: Other$9/22/2014 12:10:35 AM$Reviewer: SparkleMotion
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$1$5$"I was prescribed Lexapro for postpartum anxiety and depression.  I was on it for eight months.

column1: Starting Lexapro was tough.  Shivering with stomach cramps
column2: for a week I constantly felt like I had taken some bad
column3: terribly impure Ecstasy.  The nurse told me that this was normal.

column1: Once I became acclimated to the drug
column2: my anxiety disappeared.  That was such a relief!  However
column3: I was incredibly fatigued during the day.  I felt like I was functioning at a bare minimum
column4: day to day.

column1: I also stopped caring about most things in general.  My house wasn't as clean and creative endeavors came to a halt.  My short term memory declined.  I was necessarily unhappy about any of this; I just felt dull.  It felt like my brain was muffled.
I experienced lucid
column2: unnerving dreams/nightmares most nights while taking Lexapro.  My mind went to really dark places
column3: leaving me both frightened and exhausted.  I often woke up in the morning with my upper back muscles frozen in tension
column4: feeling as if I had not slept at all.

column1: I am fairly thin to begin with
column2: but I gained 8 pounds in the eight months I took it
column3: all in my middle.  It took a long time to get this off afterward.

column1: Getting off Lexapro was also tough
column2: with back pain
column3: insomnia
column4: and 10 days of ""brain zaps"".

column1: This was an effective med for me in terms of curbing the acute anxiety I was experiencing at the time
column2: but the side effects were too difficult for me to manage over the long term."

column1: 185$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$9/3/2014 10:34:01 AM$Reviewer: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $5$5$5$"I'm in my early 60's and have
column2: over the last 5-6 years seen an increase in my anxiety levels each year.  It was getting to the point that I had anxiety problems just worrying I would have an anxiety episode.  I became somewhat claustrophobic
column3: even when in small rooms.  My anxiety level would go up and then I would worry about that
column4: which made it worse.

column1: I finally approached my physician and described my episodes to him.  He asked about depression but I felt that I did not have any symptoms.  He prescribed Lexapro 10mg
column2: once daily.  He also gave me a small amount of Xanax 0.5mg for as needed use only.

column1: The first day I had minor side effects

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $1$1$5$I was prescribed Lexapro to treat major depressive disorder and PTSD. I had tried some other medications and they made me quite sick. I started this medication at a very low dose and experienced nausea

I was so sick and tired I was unable to be active or engaged. The doctor told me this was major depressive disorder and to consider taking another medication and to up the dose of the Lexapro. I refused the second medication but did up the dose of the Lexapro. I was so sick I could barely get out of bed. Finally
column4: I told my doctor I was going off the Lexapro. He worked out how to safely lower my dose and warned me that I may have flu like symptoms and that if I did I was to slow the lowering. I did not have flu like symptoms
column5: but I felt more desperately depressed and out of control than I had in a long long time. Extreme dizziness
column6: nausea and hysterical crying lasted about a week through the tapering of the medication. Finally off the medication
column7: I no longer feel sick. While I do continue to have symptoms of depression and PTSD
column8: they are nothing compared to sickness I felt on this medication. The Lexapro and response to my symptoms by my doctor robbed me of 6 months of my life. The traumatic event that the doctor kept prescribing me drugs for was never as horrible as being on this medication. While it clearly does work for many people
column9: it does not work for all. If you feel like you may benefit from this medication and want to give it a try
column10: I would not discourage that; however
column11: if it does not work
column12: listen to yourself and trust yourself.

column1: 259$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$12/30/2013 7:39:14 PM$Reviewer: Lexa
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $3$2$5$I was around 30 when I was prescribed Lexapro.  At the time I was a very successful Realtor and was quite stressed with work.  I noticed I was forgetting basic things like what I had for breakfast
column3: did I have breakfast
column4: did I feed the dog? My short term memory was crap and it was starting to affect my life.  I couldn't remember parts of conversations.  People were telling me things that I did or said and I honestly couldn't remember it.  I had to start trusting other people's memories more than mine which I didn't like.  This went on for under 2 yrs then my doctor figured it was anxiety and we gave this a try.  I wasn't on it for very long because even though it 'mellowed me out' and I did feel less stressed from my job it was the worst.  I didn't want to get confrontational with anyone and wanted to avoid people
column5: I only wanted to be around friends/family.  I didn't want to take phone calls or answer emails.  It basically turned me from a tiger to a kitten... which was a problem when people hired the tiger.  It made me sheepish
column6: which might work out for some people but I wouldn't recommended it for any professional that has to deal with confrontation or needs to be assertive for work.  I felt very much not like myself on it.

column3: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Within 4 months
column4: hubby dx'd w/cancer
column5: mother had major stroke
column6: many more smaller issues
column7: including memopause.  Constant anxiety
column8: no sleep
column9: mind did not stop running
column10: felt like my body was flying away from me in all different directions.  Got close to a total mental break down.  Was given Lexapro
column11: 10/mg daily
column12: within a week I was sleeping & started to be able to cope again.  No side effects
column13: no weight gain.  After 1st year
column14: needed a refill & was terrified MD would not refill because I felt wonderful on it.  I took it for another year (2 years total).  Mom passed away & hubby in remission.  Felt I needed to try life again without it.  I weaned myself off over a 2 month period skipping days inbetween until my last bottle was gone.  Two months was not long enough for the 'weaning period'
column15: I had most of the withdrawal side effects already mentioned off & on for about 6-8 months after.  It wasn't fun
column16: but my only regret is that I did not 'wean' long enough.  If I ever needed it again
column17: it would be my drug of choice.  However
column18: I would do a much longer weaning period & research how to do so correctly. It's a wonderful drug to get you through when life events are too much to handle.

column1: 294$Condition: Panic Disorder$10/7/2013 10:36:05 PM$Reviewer: J
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $4$4$3$"I started taking Lexapro after having repeated severe panic attacks and developed panic and anxiety disorder 2 years ago.

column1: Lexapro was VERY difficult to take for the first 2 months as it increased my panic attacks and anxiety levels drastically. I held out
column2: though
column3: and eventually
column4: the initial symptoms faded and my anxiety and panic attacks were roughly 20% of what they were before I was taking Lexapro. So it did work. Mostly.

column1: After a year
column2: I decided to drop from 10 mg/day to 5 mg/day and this was the most difficult part of being on the drug
column3: hands down. I experienced severe dizziness
column4: migraines
column5: confusion
column6: brain ""zaps""
column7: exhaustion
column8: repeated panic attacks(worse than before I was even taking Lexapro)
column9: insomnia
column10: nausea
column11: vomiting
column12: and constant anxiety. Again
column13: though
column14: I held out
column15: and it took about 8 weeks
column16: but I leveled out and finally felt normal again.

column1: 6 months later
column2: I chose to drop from my 5 mg/day dosage to nothing
column3: under my doctor's supervision. I was expecting the severe withdrawal symptoms again but have been very surprised that the symptoms this time have been minimal. Dizziness
column4: brain ""zaps""
column5: and some confusion the first week
column6: but after that
column7: not much else.

column1: I've been completely off of Lexapro for 4 weeks now and my anxiety has crept up somewhat...I'm at about 50% of the anxiety I was at 2 yrs ago. But I've also been in psychotherapy for 2 yrs and am continuing with therapy
column2: as I know that Lexapro was more of a coping mechanism than anything. It won't fix you
column3: but it will make life easier while you work on fixing yourself.

column1: I'm not sure I would have made it through the last 2 yrs of therapy without Lexapro and I'm grateful for that. But I would not recommend staying on the drug if you're at a point where you are able to wean yourself off. column1: 315$Condition: Depression$8/21/2013 10:10:58 PM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $3$1$3$"I was given Lexapro when I was 14 years old. I stopped taking it when I was 23. Coming off of this medication was one of the hardest things I ever did
column2: but I am a much better person for it. Most people don't need to be on these types of pills
column3: and some people do. You are strong enough to get off this medication and change the things in your life that are causing you to take it in the first place. I recently spent a month in the ICU of a hospital where I had a sudden perforated gastric ulcer which no doctors could figure out what caused. I never had problems with acid in my stomach or abdominal pain or any other symptom of an ulcer until it perforated and it was the most excruciating pain I have ever felt. After doing research
column4: I found out that the cause of my perforated ulcer was most likely the Lexapro paired with NSAID pain relievers. These medications cause more harm than is worth making you ""happy"". I strongly advise not taking these types of anti-depressants unless it is your absolute last resort. Coming off Lexapro was a horrible experience
column5: with all the withdrawal symptoms but putting those chemicals in my body was not worth it. It will take you a while to feel like a brand new person but in the end it is all worth it."

I gained weight and didn't want to do anything.  Lethargic.  At first it worked great but quickly went to laying around all the time and not feeling motivated.  It's hard to get adjusted to and takes time.  Give yourself time and be patient. It did have some sexual sides effects but when my doctor put me on Wellbutrin it offset that side effect and I was back to having orgasms but I couldnt take the weight gain and tired feeling. column1:
370$Condition: Panic Disorder$4/18/2013 2:35:50 PM$Reviewer: stayhopeful, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $5$5$5$After dealing with generalized anxiety for most of my life, I suddenly began to have severe panic attacks. In the span of almost 2 years, I became a different person, scared to do anything I used to be able to do, traffic, severe weather, being alone, sleeping, traveling, crowded spaces, elevators, almost anything and everything would trigger a meltdown and a panic attack which in turn, made me start feeling depressed and wanted to avoid pretty much everything but my bed. I even went to the hospital twice and was given Xanax to help as needed. But finally after a beginning therapy recently, I decided to give in and try medication in conjunction with talk therapy, which even that produced heavy anxiety for me. My general dr. gave me Lexapro and I began with 5mg daily. I also decided to stop taking birth control (Loestrin Fe 24) when I began the Lexapro, which I felt like exacerbated my depression and hormone levels. The Lexapro medication side effects included drowsiness and frequent yawning which made me feel like I couldn't breathe producing more anxiety initially. BUT, finally after 2 - 3 weeks I felt like a “normal human” again and suffer from absolutely NO side effects. After 2+ months of taking this medication (I have stayed on 5mg/daily), I am back to my productive and excited self. I have been able to do almost everything again and have not suffered from any panic attacks since I began the medication. I do still have negative thoughts and cognitions of catastrophes happening randomly, but I am able to stop myself and think positive without any physical sensations of panic. I feel wonderful and I am sooo happy to be on this medication!! Don't give up, stay strong and you will and can conquer this!

385$Condition: Depression$3/25/2013 3:31:36 PM$Reviewer: Les, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$I have suffered from major depression and anxiety for over two decades.  Lexapro is the best of all the a/ds I've taken.  I've taken many.  I think Lexapro is the purest of the SSRIs. Its been clean and effective.  By clean, I mean the initial side effect was minor: stomach upset for 2 or 3 days.  I think that's a good start compared to the side effects of most a/ds.  I started feeling noticeably better in two weeks.  I'm now completing the first month and I don't think I'm done improving.  This medication allows me to function normally. No more black hole sadness, most anxiety gone, no feelings of baseless guilt, worthlessness, etc.  Little things don't freeze me into inaction. I'm starting to enjoy life again.  I even laugh now and then.  Lexapro has really helped-- but I still have to put my best foot forward each day to cognitively add to the chemical boost of Lexapro. Only concern now:  No ejaculation.  I can still get an erection with the help of an e.d. med. I'm holding out a slim hope that with time my body will adjust and I'll return somewhere close to normal.  For now, though, feeling better is the most important aspect of my life.  So far, so good.

431$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$1/13/2013 6:44:10 PM$Reviewer: Lauren, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$4$It took approximately 2 weeks for the full effects to kick in but when it did
column2: I felt better than I had in my entire life in regards to mood stability and anxiety. Now I sweat less
column3: my face flushes less
column4: I can think clearer when under stress and I don't get in fits of rage as I used to w/o it. The down side of this drug is that while it eliminates the worst end of the spectrum of my mood it also takes away the tip top feeling of joy at the extreme other end of the spectrum of my mood. And lastly
column5: when I have attempted to wean myself off of this drug the side effects are so overbearing and uncomfortable that I have just had to accept that I will be taking this drug for as long as I live as the side effects lingered as long as 4 weeks when I tried to get off of it. Brain zaps
column6: disorientation
column7: inability to think clearly
column8: anxiety
column9: irritability
column10: rage
column11: clumsiness & weight gain were all the symptoms I continuously experienced when I stopped taking this drug. But I LOVE it when I am take it. I only take 20mgs once daily.

432$Condition: Depression$1/13/2013 5:20:24 PM$Reviewer: 13-18 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $1$1$5$lexapro made me exhausted. i havent done anything since ive started taking it and it just made my depression worse. it also makes me tense and i grind my teeth all the time which is causing really bad headaches. 
433$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$1/10/2013 7:16:04 PM$Reviewer: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$5$5$i can not tell I'm taking it at all,until I miss a dose .one dose makes a big change
434$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$1/10/2013 12:04:18 PM$Reviewer: tpakido, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $2$1$5$Rx'd for Anxiety
column2: GAD
column3: MDD. After being on Zoloft for several years
column4: when my depression and Anxiety spectrum returned we decided to try Lexapro. It just never felt 'right' from day 1. After several months
column5: I noticed the feelings did not improve and I figured I would need to live with it. I tried varying doses
column6: from 5 MG up to 20MG. Nothing worked. Now almost a year since starting
column7: I've made the switch back to a low dose of Zoloft. Within weeks
column8: I again feel 'normal' and I am not plauged by the overall unease I felt on Lexapro.

column1: More specifically
column2: the negative: increased anxiety
column3: developing agoraphobia
column4: EXTREME laziness and no motivation
column5: obssessive thoughts and headaches
column6: jaw clenching/bruxism caused a bit of damaged to my TMJ
column7: memory became an issue
column8: cost (even the generic.) Withdrawal
column9: even on a taper back over to Zoloft
column10: is difficult. A lot of agitation
column11: anger and headpains/aches that are beyond description.

column1: The positive: hardly any sexual side effects. Upon first taking it one year ago
column2: for a few weeks there was a bit of unexpected euphoria. For me
column3: that was short lived and slowly the negative impacts crept in.

column1: Being mindfull now
column2: everyone IS different. We all are wired uniquely and our chemistry varies--other conditions may add or detract from how a drug works for you. I know many people who love Lexapro and it has worked well for them (interestingly
column3: the ones I know have all been female! Just coincidence
column4: but interesting). It wasn't for me
column5: though. Which is why I always suggest to keep trying until you find something that works."

I recently started up on it after I had lost 40 pounds without it. I notice that I am slowly eating more and my weight is increasing a little. column1: 460$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$11/6/2012 1:08:44 AM$Reviewer: ItsaJustaCorazon
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$4$5$"This worked for me within days. It doesn't make me tired at all. I built up a resistance in about 2 months that caused the doctor to increase the dose from 10 to 20 mg daily.

column1: The first time I took Lexapro I was also depressed. I stopped taking it after 1 month and it was a small dose. It made me less depressed so I would consider it to have worked.
I have never continued to take it once I started feeling ""normal"" again.
This time I continued taking it way beyond the point of my ""Normal"". It had a Manic effect on me as best as I can tell. I have never felt like that before.
I was feeling great!
I was getting a solid 4 hours of sleep a night and was able to get up in the morning a few hours ahead of schedule. I even felt good about my work and home environment.
BUT

I starting singing aloud for no reason. I couldn't stop talking to myself. I decided to make up some imaginary friends to entertain myself. I was unable to control my thougths without shutting down or giving it my full concentration. I got angry over nothing. I started thinking about killing myself. I became paranoid and stressed out over my living situation. I came very close to doing something that I really couldn't control. Very scary way to be
column2: not in control of your brain when you really need to be. I took risks that I wouldn't normally take. I went to the doctor and we both agreed to stop taking it right away.

column1: Before this antidepressiant
column2: I was taking prozac for depression. This works much better for me than Prozac and I didn't see any side effects other than going Manic. I think I should have stopped taking it once I hit my ""Normal"" like I did before."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$4$"Went to my GP with anxiety and muscle clenching that resulted from ""body memory"" triggered by an incident that happened when I was a young child and came up in hypnotherapy 40 years later. My body reacted very badly and it got to a stage it could not function and was in fight or flight state ALL the time though I was not  depressed. She put me on 10mg of lexapro for the PTSD
column3: initial side effects were jaw clenching (subsided after maybe 2 months) and yawning excessively.  I did get some headaches and occassional nausea.  I have not gained weight.  Take it morning time. My body has relaxed and I've been calmer then ever I can remember.  Just completed 6 months on it and have decided today to come off it (cold turkey as no more pills and will see what happens). column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $3$2$5$I began taking Lexapro after my second child was born because I seemed to be having postpartum depression. The drug was prescribed by my family doctor.I started at 10mg once per day for two months and increased to 20 mg per day for the remainder of the time.I stayed on the medication for 6 months and decided to come off of it because of the side effects. The side effects included low sex drive and an increase in appetite (weight gain of about 13 pounds). I did consult my doctor about ending the medication. I had to gradually decrease the dose and then stop all together. The withdrawal from the medication was really bad
column3: I actually felt worse then before I took the medication. The withdrawal lasted about 2 weeks for me. I believe Lexipro worked well for me but the side effects were too much. I did switch to Wellbutrin XL and it seemed to work great and i had no side effects that i could identify. Just a little info for nursing mothers alway use caution while nursing and using medication. I had one doctor tell me Wellbutrin XL was ok and another told me not to use it. I did choose to come off of it altogether just recently. Also
column4: be aware of what your doctor prescribes for you. I had a pharmacy give me the wrong dosage of medication
column5: I did not know it was wrong because i never seen the actual prescription
column6: it was called in for me. Hope this helps someone out there. Just remember medications will effect everyone in differant ways
column7: so what happens to one person may not happen to another:)

Also I've had bad diarhhea and nausea while on the generic. It costs about 10 bucks less than the name brand so in my opinion it's just not worth it. I might as well take Lexapro which helps more without the side effects.

column1: 569$Condition: Depression$4/8/2012 4:32:08 AM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year$3$2$3$"I've had two major depressive episodes and decided to take Lexapro for the last one. I have also tried Zoloft and Prozac in the past and generally do not take medication between episodes. Lexapro worked quickly and well--I felt improvements within a week and completely recovered after about two months. It's clearly effective. I do have some complaints
column2: however: 1. First and foremost
column3: Lexapro has a nasty withdrawal. I have never had a problem coming off SSRIs in the past but had significant trouble with this one. Tons of ""brain zaps
column4: irritability
column5: mood swings
column6: etc. It's a real pain to taper off. Make sure to do it very carefully
column7: slowly
column8: and under supervision. If you taper off too quickly
column9: you could end up depressed all over again. 2. Sexual side effects were the worst of any SSRI I've taken. In my case
column10: much lower libido and difficulty reaching orgasm. Most SSRIs have these extremely unfortunate side effects
column11: but this one gave me the most trouble. 3. Dosing is a bit awkward. 10mg didn't work quite well enough for me and 20mg worked but made me feel like a spaced-out zombie. I was too frustrated by the end to try 15
column12: admittedly
column13: but there isn't much room for finding an ideal dosage. 4. Extremely expensive if insurance doesn't cover it. It's set to go generic this year
column14: although I don't have the latest news on this. Every medication works different for everybody
column15: and this was only my experience. I would first and foremost say that if you feel depressed or anxious
column16: make sure you see a therapist and make appropriate lifestyle changes. If you need an antidepressant
column17: I would recommend Prozac--very cheap
column18: works for me at the minimal dose (20mg) and no withdrawal. Maybe this will work for you
column19: but I won't be taking it again."

column1: 581$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$3/24/2012 6:15:21 PM$Reviewer: Gentleman415
column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $1$1$1$I have General Anxiety Disorder and was prescribed Lexapro 10mg after I suffered a panic attack trading stocks during the market meltdown of ‘08. I have never been depressed in my life but was prescribed primarily an antidepressant.  SSRI’s like Lexapro are like old phone cameras. Yes they can take pictures (treat anxiety)
column3: but their primary use is making phone calls (treating depression). Benzodiazepines on the other hand are your true high quality 5
column5: 15 megapixels dedicated digital cameras (only for anxiety).  For nearly 4 years I have taken Lexapro with little to no benefit.  I have gained 25lbs despite being healthy and active and my sex drive has diminished substantially.  About 3 weeks ago I decided to quit Lexapro and my doctor put me on .5mg of Clonazipam 2x per day.  WOW I have regained my sanity and nerves.  It really calms me down in just about 20-35 min and relaxes me for about 8hrs.  Oh yeah the sex is much better already too. I am still working on the extra weight. Bottom line is if your problem is anxiety
column6: take the dedicated medication for it. Benzo’s will work in minutes
column7: not like SSRI’s that work in weeks if at all. This with therapy and counseling should do the trick. Hope this helps and good luck to all!

column1: 597$Condition: Depression$3/5/2012 3:13:47 PM$Reviewer: mikec
column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$5$"Drug was prescribed for presumed acute depression to me by GP doctor and no information of warning to any side effects were discussed with me or spouse. I was told that this drug should just make me feel better in terms of missing energy. I was provided 10 boxes containing 10 (10)mg tablets by his office along with a prescription for 90 tablets.

column1: Timeline:
1-	Visited Doctor on about 3rd week of February 2011 and began prescription of one 10mg tablet of Lexapro a day.
2-	Consumed the initial office provided tablets by which a prescription was filled for 90 tablets on May 26 2011
3-	59 tablets were consumed and prescription stopped (cold turkey) on or around July 24 2011
4-	 Unbeknown to us  due to the absence of any discussion
column2: pamphlet
column3: ect. I was launched into state of mania shortly after discontinuing Lexapro medication.

column1: 5-	On August 3rd I submitted my resignation to my employer after 21 year 6 months of service with a fictitious place of employment going forward as I was in a manic state.
6-	During the remainder of time I acted in words only (email) in a very hostile manner to many layers of upper management essentially black balling myself.

7-	Over the month of August I found myself reacting in a hostile manner with three individuals in public with no reason and only due to the manic state I incurred from Lexapro. None of these encounters turned physical.
8-	I entered into a sales agreement for 150k to acquire a new boat. Grandiose spending.
9-	After the surrender of my Company provided car on August 29th I proceeded to purchase a new BMW lease car (500.00 per month) without an income. Grandiose spending.
10-	This manic state persisted until end of October where a very deep depression ensued.

In trying to recollect this occurrence I have found the FDA issued materials in regard to consuming Lexapro. None of the items within this material were at any  point ever outlined of discussed with me. None of the screening questions for this medication were ever discus"

column1: 605$Condition: Obsessive Compulsive Disorder$2/25/2012 6:29:13 PM$Reviewer: Anonymous, 13-18 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $2$3$4$Hi
column2: I am 18 years old and have been on Lexapro for a total of 7 years
column3: almost half of my life. I am at 40 mg a day
column4: the highest possible dose
column5: and I'm just here to warn you all
column6: the effects WEAR OFF. I was put on this antidepressant at age 11
column7: due to my issue of dwelling on every little thing I heard (i.e. scary story told at summer camp) and a tendency to repeat phrases in my head. However
column8: I was only 11 years old
column9: and I have been dependent on the drug since. I got off of it for a year and was put back on it after trying several other antidepressants. This drug has helped my personality and thoughts remain stable and it is a nightmare when I forget to take it because I become very irritable and angry with everything
column10: two symptoms I did not suffer from before taking this med. It has been a blessing but I know I would've been better off never taking it in the first place. I have mixed feelings for it because now it is my sanity pill. I am writing this as a warning to worried mothers looking to ""help"" their children
column11: do not resort to prescription drugs. It has set me up for a life of dependency and seems to have caused more problems than not
column12: as I am taking it for more reasons than I started with. If your child is suffering from weird thoughts or depression take him to a therapist
column13: as putting him/her on meds may help temporarily but will undoubtedly interfere with their quality of life and the ability to live a fulfilled one without depending on a drug/drugs. Please take my advice. The only benefits I notice from this drug are when I haven't taken it for awhile and then resume to take it
column14: because it helps with the side effects of withdrawal
column15: i.e. anger
column16: mood swings
column17: etc."

column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I love lexapro.  Although it supposedly takes time to build in your system
column3: I felt that I was more relaxed almost immediately.  I had been experiencing fighT or flight nightmares that stopped once I started lexapro and it helped me cope with annoying
column4: anxiety-provoking coworkers.   My insurance company suggested I try a different ssri that caused me to have an angry emotional outburst so I immediately switched back with doctor's paperwork required.  We have to pay more and my insurance makes me get 20 mg pills that I have to cut in half

column1: 618$Condition: Panic Disorder$2/13/2012 11:50:01 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$3$5$"I took Lexapro for my anxiety disorder Feb. 2008-July 2010. The only noticable side effect was fatigue which was mitigated by taking it after dinner. Otherwise the anxiety became manageable.
Over time I noticed that my attention suffered
column2: it became harder to feel emotions
column3: and my sex drive was definitely lowered. All of this was a willing tradeoff to anxiety.

column1: Keep in mind
column2: this drug does not cure anxiety. Like it or not
column3: it's something we will always live with. I used my time on Lexapro to learn coping mechanisms and better stress management.

column1: I decided myself to stop taking Lexapro summer 2010. If a doctor told you this medication is not habit forming (like mine did) then they weren't entirely honest. If I tried to quit cold-turkey I had moderate withdrawal symptoms. I had to gradually lower the dosage over two months
column2: but even then I would have mild dizzy spells and developed a strange nervous tick for a month.

column1: After the withdrawal period I was fine. I then moved 1000 miles
column2: started graduate school
column3: and entered into one of the most stressful years of my life. The coping mechanisms work like a charm and I haven't had major anxiety issues since. However
column4: the attention problems remain
column5: though it's another thing I just learned to live with."

column5: and the side effects are descreasing. I feel better about life; I'm laughing again and friends are noticing the difference in me. My advice for those experiencing side effects is to give the drug a chance. I hate what I call the ""psychotropic nightmare"" of changing anti-depressants

column1: 632$Condition: Repeated Episodes of Anxiety$1/25/2012 11:23:52 PM$Reviewer: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $4$3$3$"I started taking 10mg when I started feeling anxious and having panic attacks at work. This would include having hot flashes
column2: blushing.. and headaches. The first two weeks of taking lexapro I was nauseated
column3: dizzy
column4: couldnt sleep and no appetite. I was constantly yawning.. it does something to that area of your brain.. I wasnt tired.. but still couldnt stop yawning all the time. The medication worked well for turning off the voices and the over analyzing I was doing. I decided to go off the med in December deciding it wasnt worth being on when I go to have a baby. I had a horrible experience: really nauseas
column5: headaches.. really bad anxiety.. irritable. . then I ended up having a cronic migraine and went to the ER not beging able to talk or see. SCARY! If you plan on going off lexapro before any big event in your life.. i.e pregnancy.. give yourself a lot of time to wean off.. its AWFUL! I was at my wits end with the way I was feeling.. and contimplated going back on just to make it stop.. Im so glad I'm not off the drug and feeling back to normal.. anxiety free!  If you plan on taking this medication for a long period of time thats fine...but for the short-term.. think twice.. I would suggest seeking therapy instead!

654$Condition: Depression$12/29/2011 9:28:34 PM$Reviewer: Tawana76, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$5$5$Lexapro is the only medication that has helped me with my episodes. I'm not as angry when I take them. And it's been about 6 yrs or so now. But going threw withdrawls while you're pregnate has been a nightmare. I'm 35 and wasn't planning on getting pregnate. The hormone impalance and withdrawl from lexapro. OMG!! Working full time and having severe rushes from the lexapro withdrawl. I still get rushes and it's been two weeks since I took my last dose. After learning the hard way DO NOT TRY TO QUIT COLD TURKEY!!!!! And for me the main side effect was diariaha. 
655$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$12/28/2011 2:46:02 AM$Reviewer: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$2$5$I loved the way Lexapro made me feel. I felt like I had complete control of my emotions, and a far more extensive range than other antidepressants had allowed me, e.g. Zoloft and Paxil. However, I am five foot three and always weighed under one hundred and five pounds, and have been very active and proud of my toned stature. In the first year I started lexapro, went from less than one hundred and ten pounds to just under one hundred and sixty. Not only was the sudden, SIXTY POUND, weight gain  enormous (despite my seven day a week intensive martial arts exercise and healthy eating) a shock), but it  happened over six months, which caused serious pressure on my muscles, skin, and general energy level. I was an extremely fit, athletic person who suddenly lost all physical confidence despite feeling emotionally great. I switched to Wellbutrin XL three months ago and have already lost over thirty pounds without any exercise, so I am in no doubt that this horrible medicine ruined my confidence, relationship, and sex life. Lexapro made exercise and diet useless, and the mere switch, even eating whatever I wanted and exercising a minimal level, led to an extreme change.

column1: 696$Condition: Panic Disorder$11/2/2011 8:53:51 PM$Reviewer: Lifeexperience
column2: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$2$1$I have been dealing with anxiety (GADS) for as long as I remember.  I was on 25mg Paxil Cr for a great 10 years then all of a sudden it stopped working for me.  Instead of uping my dose of Paxil a doctor put me on Cipralex.  Started at 10mg
column3: felt good for a week then anxiety hit me
column4: went up to 15mg and I felt terribly sick
column5: after another week my GP put me on 20mg
column6: I lasted 3 weeks at the 20mg and I just couldn't take it no more.  I was so sick.  I didn't eat for weeks
column7: stomach upset
column8: nausea
column9: headaches
column10: jitters
column11: crying fits
column12: more anxiety.  I was scared to be alone.  It was effecting my home life drastically. I ended up in emergency because of extreme dizzyness and throwing up.  The emerg doc said go back down to 10mg.  He thought it was to strong.  I got a couple shots in the arse.  One for nausea and other for stomach upset.  I was advised to see my regular GP.  The next day I seen my GP (Crying the whole time)  He basically said he didn't know what to do with me.  He put me back on a low dose of Paxil (12.5) and put a requisition in for me to see a psyciatrist (which will take 2 months to be able to see one)  So now I am dosing myself out with Clonozapam (1mg twice a day)..not driving...not working.  Keeping my child home from school to look after me (not fair!) and my husband gets home as soon as he can after work at each  night. I have never felt this bad/depressed and down right scared like this before.  Hoping the paxil cr will kick in quick so my family can stop worrying about me.  Never will I take Cipralex again!

After years of Chronic pain I have now developed some depression and I suppose it does have some effect in controlling it but I still get times of deep depression

But you have to pull your mind together and thank God that you are not in worse shape like some others have to suffer through or live and Rubuke those thoughts of feeling sorry for yourself or cheated out of life!  Your still living right?  So live life to the fullest way that YOU can is what I have learned.  Ultimately you are in control of your mind

It was very effective and I used it for about four years.  During that four years, I gained 110 pounds and did not even care--in fact, I cared about nothi8ng at all, or even doing anything at all.  Libdo went to absolutely zero.  Zombiefied.  Stopped taking the drug and developed severe anxiety attacks requiring another medication.  Additional negative side effects were slow but continual increasing nerve pain in feet and along the side of left leg.  Pain also began in right leg after experienceing it in left for several months. These pains totally disappeared in about two weeks after stopping Lexapro.  Evaluation is the drug does counteract depression but it can have severe side effects.  Be very careful and watch for adverse effects.  I would NOT recommend it to anyone.
702$Condition: Other$10/26/2011 10:15:23 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$5$5$I am 40 year old fit male.  I've been on 10mg of Lexapro for 2 years for anxiety due to loss of a very high income Wall Street job.  It took the edge off and allowed me to make very rational career
column2: financial
column3: and family decisions without unnecessary anxiety.  I have never been depressed.   Over two years
column4: the side effects were 20-30 lbs of increased weight
column5: and annoying decreased libido.

column1: Last week I've decided to transition to Wellbutrin XL and stop taking Lexapro.  The half-life of Lexapro is 27 hours
column2: so I decided to taper Lexapro with the following schedule: Day0 10mg
column3: Day1 5mg
column4: Day2 5mg
column5: Day3 2.5 mg
column6: Day4 2.5mg
column7: Day5 0mg
column8: Day6 0mg.  Today is the end of Day6.  I’ve only had two withdrawal symptoms that are minor: slight dizziness and elevated tinnitus.  Tomorrow I will begin Wellbutrin XL 100mg.  I am hopeful that Wellbutrin will have the same calming effects  and completely reverse the weight gain and decreased libido.

column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Caregiver) $1$1$5$"14 yr old son has sleep disorder from age 2. Lack of sleep caused performance anxieties leading to depression. Pediatrician prescribed Lexapro. Coaches reported he seemed more relaxed but at home he seemed to no longer care about anything
column3: or anyone. Personality change
column4: lost all empathy
column5: became mean
column6: agressive
column7: and violent. Side effects included extreme fatigue
column8: which made anxiety and depression worse
column9: weight gain
column10: agitation
column11: dizziness
column12: light-headed
column13: tingling. Couldn't get up for school
column14: confrontational with teachers
column15: GPA drop from 3.989 to 2.929. Weaned off over 1 month
column16: immediate improvement but personality changes still remain to some degree. Devastating effects on entire family and almost destroyed our business at same time. Drs should not prescribe to youth and should be more aware of physical and mental side-affects and provide more warnings. We force our kids to keep taking when they complain because Dr says to. I'm thankful we didn't end up with violent or suicidal actions. I'd rather deal with the original problems vs just covering them up and dealing with the even worse side-affects.

Coaches reported he seemed more relaxed but at home he seemed to no longer care about anything, or anyone. Personality change, lost all empathy,became mean, agressive, and violent. column2: 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $4$3$1$"I started having panic attacks in 1988. In 1994
column3: I started taking Klonopin. 2 1/2 years ago
column4: a new Dr. reduced my Klonopin by 1/3 and started me on 10 mg of Lexapro.

column1: Benefits
1. almost no panic attacks in the past 2 1/2 years
column2: and no worries or fears about public speaking or other causes of the panic attacks.

column1: 2. No immediate side effects after initial dosages.
Longer term Side Effects
1. Trouble sleeping at night - wake up many times during the night and then have trouble waking in the AM.
2. Gained 15 to 20 lbs and have voracious appetite.
3. Initial sexual side effects but subsided after a few weeks.
4. VERY VIVID and LONG dreams (they are actually quite enjoyable)
5. Recently been experiencing memory loss and absent-minded-ness ( this last one is very concerning).
HAS ANYONE ELSE EXPERIENCED the dreams and memory loss?"

column1: 821$Condition: Posttraumatic Stress Syndrome$6/10/2011 4:48:35 AM$Reviewer: exParaeducator
column2: 55-64 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $1$1$2$"I was originally prescribed Lexapro during cancer treatment while working in a warzone called middle school. I was told it would help with symptoms of sudden menopause brought on by my cancer treatment. It didn’t. To my detriment
column3: it enabled me to remain in a dangerous work environment for longer than I could have withstood it otherwise. I experienced many of the main complaints that others report including massive weight gain
column4: total loss of libido
column5: suicidal ideation
column6: screaming nightmares
column7: hypervigilance
column8: and rages.  I also experienced severe withdrawal on two occasions. Once I could not get my medication on time through the mail order program I was forced to use. And once I left town without my medication. I became ill within hours of missing a dose and for three days was too ill to get myself back home. My symptoms included nausea
column9: vomiting
column10: the shakes
column11: cold sweats
column12: loss of coordination
column13: and diminished cognition. I was given Lexapro in combination with other drugs
column14: first one and then another
column15: but Lexapro was the main one for an extended period. At one point
column16: I was given dosing instructions for extended release capsules on a prescription of short acting tablets of Effexor. I had severe problems while on these drugs
column17: ending up in the ER twice with symptoms of cardiomyopathy brought on by severe anxiety. It’s a wonder I lived through it. I’m not sure I will ever fully recover from it. My career ended as a result as did my sex life and my enjoyment of many activities I used to love. I am living a diminished life due to depression and anxiety and a new doctor wants me to try Lexapro again. I have decided not to risk revisiting that awful experience. For me
column18: depression and anxiety are preferable to being driven stark raving mad due to having my brain chemistry altered
column20: on drugs the effects of which are poorly understood at best and have the potential to cause irreversible harm at worst.

column1: 936$Condition: Other$3/7/2011 11:36:57 PM$Reviewer: Lionheart
column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient) $5$5$5$"Lexapro changed my life. I use this primarily for anxiety
column3: and secondarily for depression. As I went off to college and began my life on my own
column4: I realized how much anxiety I have and how difficult it makes life. I dropped out of college twice due to my anxiety. I had such terrible social anxiety that if I missed a class
column5: I would be too afraid to even ask my teacher about what I missed. This would lead to an endless cycle of missing class and being to afraid to attend again. It also would lead to a helpless depression. I never went out or made new friends. It sounds stupid to be ""afraid"" of social situations
column6: but it was ruining my life. Until I tried Lexapro
column7: I had no idea how much anxiety I really had. I discovered that my life was being controlled by my anxiety. I couldn't even make phone calls to talk to people I didn't know or approach people
column8: even in a professional setting. I couldn't get a job because I was to anxious to even go into a facility and ask for an application
column9: let alone have a interview. I am now working full-time and going to college full-time
column10: and have not had anxiety since I've been taking Lexapro. This medication has really been the best thing I have ever taken. The best way I can describe this medication is if you imagine having a light switch in your brain for anxiety/fear
column11: and this just switches it off. I haven't had any negative side-effects from this
column12: and only have good things to say."

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient) $4$4$4$"I have been on for 5 days and can already tell a difference.  I don't feel like i see two people looking at me in the mirror.  One of them I know and the other I don't.

column1: 958$Condition: Depression$2/9/2011 3:45:44 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient) $5$3$5$"This is an excellent medication for treating depression.  I have experienced depression for over 20 years.  This is the only one that finally made me feel ""normal"".  I stopped getting angry over every little thing
column2: I stopped worrying about minor things
column3: I was very happy.  I have since weaned myself off of this drug
column4: it has taken over 9 months.  It is VERY hard to get off and you need to be committed to weaning yourself very slowly.  It will make you crazy if you don't.  The reason I am weaning myself off of this medication is for two reasons.  The first being that I have gained over 10 pounds on the 5 years that I taken it.  I CANNOT lose weight no matter how I eat or exercise. It has affected my metabolism in some way.  The second reason is that it has affected my libido in a negative way.  I have very little interest in sex.  It has not affected my ability to climax
column5: but just the ""getting going"" part.  I am now realizing that I still need medication
column6: my irritability and anxieties have returned.  I need to find something that will help me without the negative side effects."

column1: 960$Condition: Major Depressive Disorder$2/5/2011 11:46:08 PM$Reviewer: sap2491
column2: 19-24 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$5$4$Lexapro has given me my life back. Around this time a year ago
column3: I was in an ambulance on my way to the hospital for an overdose and alcohol poisoning. I had to leave college
column4: and entered a period of several weeks during which I could not even bring myself to leave my bed. I was diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder and Anxiety Disorder
column5: put on suicide watch
column6: and prescribed Lexapro. Today
column7: I am happy to report that I have found myself again. I work at a job several days a week
column8: I go out with friends
column9: and I am applying to transfer to a new college. I haven't felt the hopelessness that I used to feel in many months
column10: and I consider myself a content person. This was by no means an easy or short road. Lexapro is not a magic pill that will have you waking up the next day smiling like Vanna White. It took several difficult months of adjustment
column11: and it's not a pill that works for everyone. I still have sadness and depression occasionally
column12: like any person will. It doesn't interfere with my ability to live a happy
column13: successful life anymore
column14: though. I know that I will also face difficult when weening off the medication
column15: but I am prepared for that. The most important thing that I have learned from this is that there is never a reason to give up. Depression doesn't define you
column16: and it isn't forever. Your life isn't blanketed in nighttime like you might think
column17: it is actually just a cloud obscuring your sunlight
column18: and it's ok if you need a little help moving out from behind that cloud.

column1: 985$Condition: Depression$1/10/2011 1:21:52 PM$Reviewer: 35-44 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $4$4$5$"I first took Lexapro from 2004 - 2007 due to physical reactions to extreme stress.  I probably shouldn't have taken it then
column2: but my Dr wanted to try it and see if chest tightness
column3: panic attacks
column4: and thumpy heartbeat went away.  I did notice very vivid dreams during the first 2 weeks on it.  The dreams weren't scary
column5: just very very vivid.

column1: I stopped Lexapro in 2008 and experienced some withdrawl symptoms
column2: the worst being the ""brain zaps""
column3: feeling like electrical jolts were running through my brain.  That lasted about a week and then went away.

column1: I recently went on Lexapro again in 2010 for anxiety and depression and the return of physical symptoms (thought I was having a heart attack
column2: but it was anxiety).  Upon starting Lexapro again
column3: I didn't have any vivid dreams but my physical symptoms went away.

column1: Now I take 10 Mg/day and
column2: while the physical symptoms are gone
column3: my mood is rather neutral
column4: rather than happy or sad.  Also
column5: libido is very low.  Weight gain has occured
column6: even though I don't really feel hungry most of the time.

column1: However
column2: while some of the side effects annoying and bothersome
column3: not to mention the cost of the drug
column4: Lexapro has been very helpful in getting me out of the hole I was stuck in."

column2: 19-24 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient) $2$1$5$"I was struggling more with anxiety than depression at the time
column3: and on that note
column4: lexapro seemed to work pretty well for a while. However
column5: my depression eventually relapsed
column6: and despite continually upping the dose until it was past the range of tested clinical efficacy (40 mg)
column7: I was still depressed nearly every day for two months
column8: characterized by low energy and motivation
column9: as well as occasional
column10: fleeting suicidal ideations. I was prescribed bupropion to take in conjunction with the lexapro
column11: giving me substantial increases in energy and motivation which I felt that lexapro had sapped from me. However
column12: bupropion did nothing to fix lexapro's sexual side effects
column13: which had once been mild but were now approaching borderline-impotence. I decided that I'd enough of this; thus
column14: I tapered off the lexapro over the course of a month
column15: during which I experienced persistent ""brain zaps""
column16: increased agitation
column17: lowered energy
column21: once the influence of this horrible substance had completely left my system
column22: I began feeling back on track with the bupropion. I still suffer from depression but I'm much more functional
column24: and motivated than before.  In conclusion
column25: Lexapro did nothing but potentiate my depression.  I will never put another SSRI in my system again."

I'm frustrated that I don't seem to respond to these meds well.  I just need something to work.  I could barely leave the house the past few days.  I'll give it another 2 weeks (maybe) and if symptoms of anxiety and anger don't improve, I'm giving up on Lexapro, too.  I'm willing to put up with this very temporarily, but I was honestly doing better BEFORE starting Lex than I am now.  This med is still better than Zoloft, which was a nightmare for me. column3: I continued taking Lexapro for a week before stopping.  After another week
column4: I returned to my doctor and reported the problems.  He told me there should be no problem with other medications and to start it again.  I did
column5: but with the same results...pins and needles.  I stopped again but then started a month or so later only to have pins and needles again.  I stayed on Lexapro for about another 2-3 months.  I used Percocet to help control the pins and needles.  Those two drugs became my daily ritual.  However
column6: I moved from Lexapro to Xanax and found a lot more relief while still using the Percocet.  Later
column7: I also developed burning sensations.  I now have all three--pins
column8: needles
column9: and burning sensations (PNBS)
column10: a new acronym.  I have tried incessantly to get rid of these problems
column11: but still have them.  I basically live on oxycodone (Percocet without the Tylenol) at least 3-5 times a week with an occasional Xanax.  I've tried every herbal known to man with little success.  I contacted the makers of Lexapro to ask for a solution
column12: but their cop-out was that my doctor would have to treat me and that they could do nothing.  Now I see why people sue pharmaceutical companies.  Good luck on Lexapro.  But
column13: if you experience PNBA right away
column14: my advice is to stop it immediately and never return.  The PNBA is horrible!

column3: vivid dreams and heavy menstrual periods. I felt zoned out too. I even had a major panic attack so I stopped taking it. Well the feelings of anxiety and despair came creeping back and I started drinking again. A few months ago I decided to quit drinking for good and I started 5 mg of Lex again. No symptoms this time! After a month I went up to 10 mg and still no side effects! I feel great.. no social anxiety! I am finally able to live
column4: for myself and my children. And I am proud to say that I am 3 months sober and I believe the Lexapro has helped. The only downside is that I have heard the withdrawals are terrible. Someday I hope to be able to wean off of the meds but for now I am enjoying life again!

My mom is 87 yrs old and had to have blood transfusions twice with the total of 12 pts first time and 8 the second time a month later. column1: This drug is dangerous and should be given a better warning lable than is on there now.  I almost lost my mom in Nov 2009 and Jan 2010 before I took her off meds and told doctors I was 100% sure that was the problem.  I am not saying it is not going to help for some but not for seniors who have possible underlying conditions.  I would not want anyone to go through what I and my families have gone thru because of this. It also effected her brain function and now her memory and able to talk (slurring her words) and her gait is off really badly.  Pain mgmt dr presecribed it to her for pain not for depression.  It did take some of pain away but damaged her brain in the course of treatment."

column2: 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 5 to less than 10 years (Patient) $5$4$5$"I've used 20mg daily since its introduction in '02. Over the years Lexapro has also shown that 20mg is the average effective dose. Sex drive can be an issue if your relationship is based on same. On the other hand
column3: the love drive on this med increases significantly. If you were severely depressed and unable to eat/losing weight-you will regain your appetite-weight. column4: procrastination is a big part of being depressed... Oh yeah
column5: don't use ANY depressants (i.e. opiates
column6: cannabis
column7: benzos
column8: alcohol) at all-at all (!!!) if you expect the stuff to work. "

column1: 1166$Condition: Depression$8/12/2010 5:08:52 PM$Reviewer: Katie2650
column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient) $5$4$5$I took Lexapro (10mg daily) for almost 2 years.  It helped me control my depression and anxiety.  I knew that I had to ween off this medication slowly; I had taken other SSRIs in the past (Paxil
column3: Zoloft) and it is NOT a good idea to stop all at once
column4: you need a plan to ween off these meds.  I started to ween myself off and had terrible side affects - dizziness
column5: a strange head zapping feeling and increased anxiety.  I decided to stay on Lexapro awhile longer as I was busy with work and travel for my job and couldn't deal with a dizzy head.  A few months ago
column6: I slowly started to ween off again.  My doctor told me to cut the pill in half and take 5mg each day
column7: then after 1 week take 5mg every other day
column8: then every 2 days.  I took it even slower and took 5mg every other day for 1 month until I felt I was ready to stop completely.  I had the same side affects - dizzy head
column9: zapping feeling in my brain
column10: weird body aches.  I stuck with my plan and after 2 weeks
column11: the side affects completely disappeared and I felt completely normal.  I have not had any issues since.  My advice is to ween off slowly and stick it out if you have some mild side affects from withdrawl
column12: because they will go away.

column2: 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Caregiver) $3$3$3$please be aware of side effects of any med u take. be proactive in your care. For three years my mother suffered from a fever of unknown origin. Tylenol
column3: ibuprofin nothing could brak the fever. i took her to multiple doctors specialists. and talked her into several procedures including bone marrow biopsies and polyp removal in her sinuses to try and get rid of this debilitating fever
column4: malaise
column5: fatigue and weakness.she lost 30 punds and nearly died of dehydration.After the 20th dr said he coulnt help and she told me she was ready to pass and couldnt live like this anymore i looked lexapro up in a drug book and the symptoms she had were listed. she stopped taking lexapro and the fevers and other symptoms went away. no dr bothered to look up side effects of this med and my mother almost left us. this is not a common side effect. lexapro was the miracle drug for my own depression
column6: i wouldnt be here now without it. just please be aware of what you are taking and possible side effects. we cant leave it all to the drs we must be our own advocates in our healthcare.
